article:
By default when you import Ontologies the browser will look for the URI of the ontology present in you Ontology which import it, which can be local on your driver but also available on the Web.
But in some cases the URI might not be found, or you might no have access to the Web. For these cases you can provide a list of alternate locations which will be local on your disk to resolve these URIs.
The "Schemas Alternate Locations" setting in the allow to specify these Ontologies alternate locations.
For example suppose the folllwing Ontology, which uses the Dublin Core terms schema:
<rdf:RDF xmlns="http://www.my.uri.com/myOntology#" xml:base="http://www.my.uri.com/myOntology" xmlns:owl="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:xml="http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#" xmlns:rdfs="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#" xmlns:terms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/"> <owl:Ontology rdf:about="http://www.my.uri.com/myOntology"> <terms:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date">2012-06-14</terms:modified> <terms:publisher>This is me</terms:publisher> <terms:title>My Ontology title</terms:title> <rdfs:comment>This is an example ontology</rdfs:comment> </owl:Ontology> ... </rdf:RDF>
As you can see, the terms namespace, which is provided in http://purl.org/dc/terms/, is used in this Ontology.
You can provide the https://www.dublincore.org/specifications/dublin-core/dcmi-terms/dublin_core_elements.rdf, in this case the browser will use the local file rather that resolving it from the Web.
